    • Using survival_ln_mixture with parsnip

Using survival_ln_mixture with parsnip

parsnip_spec.Rmd

The package also provide a parsnip egine that can be used with the survival_reg model fron censored package.

library(tidymodels)
library(censored)
require(lnmixsurv)
tidymodels_prefer()

mod_spec <- survival_reg() |>
  set_engine("survival_ln_mixture",
    intercept = FALSE,
    starting_seed = 20
  ) |>
  set_mode("censored regression")
dados <- sim_data$data
set.seed(1)
mod_fit <- mod_spec |>
  fit(Surv(y, delta) ~ x, dados)
mod_fit
#> parsnip model object
#> 
#> survival_ln_mixture
#>  formula:      Surv(y, delta) ~ x + 0
#>  observations: 10000
#>  predictors:   1
#> ------
#>      estimate  std.error conf.low conf.high
#> x0_1 3.639316 0.01310024 3.620278  3.657374
#> x1_1 4.674169 0.01706678 4.651150  4.696104
#> x0_2 4.079056 0.01422397 4.060621  4.096565
#> x1_2 3.401503 0.02475422 3.364982  3.431719
#> 
#> Auxiliary parameter(s):
#>         estimate  std.error   conf.low conf.high
#> phi_1  3.4584526 0.08967301  3.3398627  3.575241
#> phi_2 10.9731414 0.77486892 10.0646470 12.132132
#> eta_1  0.7827314 0.01331543  0.7653866  0.798170

When using recipes, some caution must be taken due to the fact that recipes do not support inline functions (like survival::Surv). A possible way to use them is to set both the time and event indicator as outcomes (or predictors) and then construct the Surv object in a step_mutate, with the role seted to "outcome".

In order to make predictions in the usual way, is then necessary to remove the original time and event indicator, and set both steps with skip = TRUE, to prevent them from being baked when predicting, and thus, not needing to set these variables in new_data.

rec <- recipe(y + delta ~ x, dados) |>
  step_mutate(z = x) |>
  step_mutate(outcome = Surv(y, delta), role = "outcome", skip = TRUE) |>
  step_rm(y, delta, x, skip = TRUE)

wflw <- workflow() |>
  add_model(mod_spec) |>
  add_recipe(rec)

set.seed(1)
mod_tidy <- wflw |> fit(dados)
mod_tidy
#> ══ Workflow [trained] ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
#> Preprocessor: Recipe
#> Model: survival_reg()
#> 
#> ── Preprocessor ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> 3 Recipe Steps
#> 
#> • step_mutate()
#> • step_mutate()
#> • step_rm()
#> 
#> ── Model ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> survival_ln_mixture
#>  formula:      x ~ . + 0
#>  observations: 10000
#>  predictors:   1
#> ------
#>      estimate  std.error conf.low conf.high
#> z0_1 3.639316 0.01310024 3.620278  3.657374
#> z1_1 4.674169 0.01706678 4.651150  4.696104
#> z0_2 4.079056 0.01422397 4.060621  4.096565
#> z1_2 3.401503 0.02475422 3.364982  3.431719
#> 
#> Auxiliary parameter(s):
#>         estimate  std.error   conf.low conf.high
#> phi_1  3.4584526 0.08967301  3.3398627  3.575241
#> phi_2 10.9731414 0.77486892 10.0646470 12.132132
#> eta_1  0.7827314 0.01331543  0.7653866  0.798170

The predictions work as usual.

new_data <- dados |> distinct(x)
mod_fit |>
  predict(new_data, type = "survival", eval_time = 100) |>
  tidyr::unnest(cols = .pred)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 2
#>   .eval_time .pred_survival
#>        <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1        100         0.0374
#> 2        100         0.431

mod_tidy |>
  predict(new_data, type = "survival", eval_time = 100) |>
  tidyr::unnest(cols = .pred)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 2
#>   .eval_time .pred_survival
#>        <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1        100         0.0374
#> 2        100         0.431
